[6] Today’s high prices at the pump are the result of a coordinated attack on our energy independence. There isn’t an overnight fix. It will require an Administration-wide recommitment to America First energy policies. 
 
We need policy change, not pandering.

[5] Here’s what @POTUS SHOULD do to bring down prices at the pump: 
 
- Reopen federal lands for domestic energy 
- Expedite the approval process for oil and gas leases 
- Commit to American Energy dominance
- Restart the Keystone XL Pipeline and fast track other needed pipelines

[4] Biden is trying to have his cake and eat it too. 

He is actively pursuing policies that harm our oil and gas industry, then turning around and begging them to increase production and investment to bring prices down.

[3] When Georgia took a gas tax holiday, unsurprisingly, prices went down. At one point, we had the lowest prices in the country. 

On a state level, this move makes sense, because states have fewer resources at their disposal to address gas prices than the federal government.
[2] Essentially, we are trading high gas prices for high gas prices, while draining the resources our country needs for maintaining roadways.
[1] Currently, the federal gas tax is 18.4 cents per gallon. At best, reducing it will result in a few dollars saved per fill-up and brings us nowhere close to the ~ $2 gas we saw in 2020.

Beyond reconciliation, I’m laser focused on securing climate wins and reducing emissions wherever and whenever I can. Here are a few of those victories:

CEPP successfully advanced out of my committee with the support of myriad environmental justice organizations from across the country. Unfortunately, Senator Manchin demanded the program be removed from the package before it could come to the House floor.

That is why I have supported policies that go well-beyond the $555 billion that passed the House, including leading efforts to develop the Clean Electricity Payment Program (CEPP), a $150 billion policy to require utilities to use more renewables each year over the next decade.

While the House package was historic – we’re still a long way from seeing a reconciliation package signed into law, and even if it is, I fully acknowledge it will not solve the climate crisis on its own. 🌎
